Problem:
Consider a system modeled by the wave equation \\( u_{tt} = c^2 u_{xx} \\), where \\( c \\) is the wave speed. We investigate the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(k, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-ikx}u(x,t)dx \\) on the system and manipulating the transformed function.

If a Fourier transform is applied to the initial condition \\( u(x, 0) \\) and then the system evolves according to the wave equation without further intervention, will the solution \\( u(x, T) \\) at time \\( T \\) be the same as if the system evolved from \\( u(x, 0) \\) directly?
Explanation: The Fourier transform is a linear and reversible operation. Evolving the Fourier-transformed initial condition and then applying the inverse transform will yield the same results as directly evolving the initial condition under the wave equation, due to the linearity and time invariance of the equation.
